column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Then at last there were lights and houses and men and women passing the windows.
#Text=They had entered a village.
#Text=Instantly Flush was all attention. ". . . his eyes were starting out of his head with eagerness; he looked east, he looked west, you would conclude that he was taking notes or preparing them."
#Text=It was the human scene that stirred him, not beauty.

#Text=Beauty, so it seems at least, had to be crystallised into a green or violet powder and puffed by some celestial syringe down the fringed channels that lay behind his nostrils before it touched Flush's senses; and then it issued not in words, but in a silent rapture.
#Text=Where Mrs.
#Text=Browning saw, he smelt; where she wrote, he snuffed.
#Text=Here, then, the biographer must perforce come to a pause.
#Text=Where two or three thousand words are insufficient for what we see--and Mrs.
#Text=Browning had to admit herself beaten by the Apennines: "Of these things I cannot give you any idea," she admitted--there are no more than two words and perhaps one-half for what we smell.
#Text=The human nose is practically non-existent.
#Text=The greatest poets in the world have smelt nothing but roses on the one hand, and dung on the other.
#Text=The infinite gradations that lie between are unrecorded.
#Text=Yet it was in the world of smell that Flush mostly lived.
#Text=Love was chiefly smell; form and colour were smell; music and architecture, law, politics and science were smell.
#Text=To him religion itself was smell.
#Text=To describe his simplest experience with the daily chop or biscuit is beyond our power.
#Text=Not even Mr.
#Text=Swinburne could have said what the smell of Wimpole Street meant to Flush on a hot afternoon in June.

#Text=As for describing the smell of a spaniel mixed with the smell of torches, laurels, incense, banners, wax candles and a garland of rose leaves crushed by a satin heel that has been laid up in camphor, perhaps Shakespeare, had he paused in the middle of writing Antony and Cleopatra--But Shakespeare did not pause.
#Text=Confessing our inadequacy, then, we can but note that to Flush Italy, in these the fullest, the freest, the happiest years of his life, meant mainly a succession of smells.
#Text=Love, it must be supposed, was gradually losing its appeal.
#Text=Smell remained.
#Text=Now that they were established in Casa Guidi again, all had their avocations.
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Browning wrote regularly in one room; Mrs.
#Text=Browning wrote regularly in another.
#Text=The baby played in the nursery.
#Text=But Flush wandered off into the streets of Florence to enjoy the rapture of smell.
#Text=He threaded his path through main streets and back streets, through squares and alleys, by smell.
#Text=He nosed his way from smell to smell; the rough, the smooth, the dark, the golden.

#Text=He went in and out, up and down, where they beat brass, where they bake bread, where the women sit combing their hair, where the bird-cages are piled high on the causeway, where the wine spills itself in dark red stains on the pavement, where leather smells and harness and garlic, where cloth is beaten, where vine leaves tremble, where men sit and drink and spit and dice--he ran in and out, always with his nose to the ground, drinking in the essence; or with his nose in the air vibrating with the aroma.
#Text=He slept in this hot patch of sun--how sun made the stone reek!
#Text=he sought that tunnel of shade--how acid shade made the stone smell!

#Text=He devoured whole bunches of ripe grapes largely because of their purple smell; he chewed and spat out whatever tough relic of goat or macaroni the Italian housewife had thrown from the balcony--goat and macaroni were raucous smells, crimson smells.
#Text=He followed the swooning sweetness of incense into the violet intricacies of dark cathedrals; and, sniffing, tried to lap the gold on the window-stained tomb.
#Text=Nor was his sense of touch much less acute.
#Text=He knew Florence in its marmoreal smoothness and in its gritty and cobbled roughness.
#Text=Hoary folds of drapery, smooth fingers and feet of stone received the lick of his tongue, the quiver of his shivering snout.
#Text=Upon the infinitely sensitive pads of his feet he took the clear stamp of proud Latin inscriptions.
#Text=In short, he knew Florence as no human being has ever known it; as Ruskin never knew it or George Eliot either.
#Text=He knew it as only the dumb know.
#Text=Not a single one of his myriad sensations ever submitted itself to the deformity of words.

#Text=But though it would be pleasant for the biographer to infer that Flush's life in late middle age was an orgy of pleasure transcending all description; to maintain that while the baby day by day picked up a new word and thus removed sensation a little further beyond reach, Flush was fated to remain for ever in a Paradise where essences exist in their utmost purity, and the naked soul of things presses on the naked nerve--it would not be true.
#Text=Flush lived in no such Paradise.

#Text=The spirit, ranging from star to star, the bird whose furthest flight over polar snows or tropical forests never brings it within sight of human houses and their curling wood-smoke, may, for anything we know, enjoy such immunity, such integrity of bliss.
#Text=But Flush had lain upon human knees and heard men's voices.
#Text=His flesh was veined with human passions; he knew all grades of jealousy, anger and despair.
#Text=Now in summer he was scourged by fleas.
#Text=With a cruel irony the sun that ripened the grapes brought also the fleas. ". . .

#Text=Browning, is scarcely worse than Flush's in the summer."

column1: #Text=Fleas leapt to life in every corner of the Florentine houses; they skipped and hopped out of every cranny of the old stone; out of every fold of old tapestry; out of every cloak, hat and blanket.
#Text=They nested in Flush's fur.
#Text=They bit their way into the thickest of his coat.
#Text=He scratched and tore.
#Text=His health suffered; he became morose, thin and feverish.
#Text=Miss Mitford was appealed to.
#Text=What remedy was there, Mrs.
#Text=Browning wrote anxiously, for fleas?
#Text=Miss Mitford, still sitting in her greenhouse at Three Mile Cross, still writing tragedies, put down her pen and looked up her old prescriptions--what Mayflower had taken, what Rosebud.
#Text=But the fleas of Reading die at a pinch.
#Text=The fleas of Florence are red and virile.
#Text=To them Miss Mitford's powders might well have been snuff.
#Text=In despair Mr. and Mrs.
#Text=Browning went down on their knees beside a pail of water and did their best to exorcise the pest with soap and scrubbing-brush.
#Text=It was in vain.
#Text=At last one day Mr.
#Text=Browning, taking Flush for a walk, noticed that people pointed; he heard one man lay a finger to his nose and whisper "La rogna" (mange).
#Text=As by this time "Robert is as fond of Flush as I am," to take his walk of an afternoon with a friend and to hear him thus stigmatised was intolerable.
#Text=Robert, his wife wrote, "wouldn't bear it any longer."
#Text=Only one remedy remained, but it was a remedy that was almost as drastic as the disease itself.
#Text=However democratic Flush had become and careless of the signs of rank, he still remained what Philip Sidney had called him, a gentleman by birth.
